https://jenkins.openbmc.org/job/ci-repository/74719/ : SUCCESS
Suggest making a markdown file for the blocklist format if it isn't already documented somewhere.
Add a doc for basic usage.

Or since `bus` is loop invariant and `busBlacklist[bus]` is currently looked up multiple times on each iteration, maybe just assign `busBlacklist.find(bus)` to a variable outside the loop once and use that instead?
Move outside of loop and store addresses in the exitting skipList.
I don't think this is necessary.
I don't understand the need for this to be outside the scope.
And then what are we doing about it?  It appears that we keep going, which isn't good.
What are we doing in the error path?

This seems extraneous.  Can you put 16 into line 574?

If this was to squash a clang-tidy warning, please switch to `static constexpr auto hexbase = 16`.
Why are we getting one type (size_t) but storing into another type (bus)?
Add some condition check when loading blacklist. The situation mentioned above should be fine.
Do we want this cerr all the time?  Seems like noise.

Please wrap this line.  Also, I think it should be worded a little more strongly, something like "should not be scanned" instead of "don't need to be scan[ned]".

While it can sort of be inferred from the content, I think it would be good to mention explicitly somewhere in this document that a bare-integer entry blocks an entire bus from being scanned, while a bus/addresses object can be used for more fine-grained control to block specific addresses but allow scanning other addresses on the same bus.
This should specify that the address strings should be in hex.  (Too bad json doesn't support it natively, sigh...)

Okay, so I guess this is the fix to prevent an empty addresses array from being treated as a whole-bus block, though I have to say it seems like a bit of a hack (and also fairly non-obvious to a casual reader, especially given the continuing lack of explanatory comments).

Looking back at it, I'd be strongly in favor of a more explicit representation in the datatype used for `busBlacklist` (e.g. the std::optional<>-based approach I suggested) -- that would obviate the need for this surprising little edge-case entirely.

For the approach I'm suggesting, an entry like that (with an empty "addresses" array), would be equivalent to no entry at all -- it's saying "block no addresses on bus 3".  Yes, someone might have forgotten to add the address entries, but they could just as easily forget an entire bus entry as well, and I don't think we should be in the business of trying to guess at what someone *might* have meant if we think maybe they messed up.  I think we should define and implement explicit, clear, simple semantics and avoid magic special cases, so that things end up doing what they look like they say.
Thank you. We update a new patch for using the data type std::optional
This is three lookups in busBlacklist; it'd be nicer to do it with one lookup using the return value of `busBlacklist.find()` instead.
Formatting looks a bit off here; until CI gets fixed to do it automatically, can you run clang-format on this?
Double-lookup again here; `.find()` could be used to do it with one.
There is nullopt check on line 602. It won't get here if the bus is nullopt.
line 497 can dynamically change it to nullopt
why is size_t used here, where int is used when loading the black list line 565
skiplist at line 381 is still int. There is still implicit type conversion.
check rootBus for blocked address list?
Added nullopt check for rootBus. Is there any additional check needed for rootBus address?
if block addresses are defined for rootbus, they should be added to the logical bus.
existing return type is used in other places. Have you checked to see if it make sense to switch to size_t and there will be no implicit data conversion?
Please switch to std::from_chars(), which is more efficient

It seems like it works with std::string_view. The 'subMatch.str()' returned a temporary string and it needed extra string to keep the return value. If we make string_view point directly to 'subMatch.str()', it will make the pointer held by string_view becomes dangling pointer.
why hard coded position here? use begin and end instead?
Changed string to string_view. from_chars doesn't recognize the prefix '0x' or '0X', so it has to start the convertion at begin()+2.
LGTM with latest patch. Leave it up for couple more days to see if there is more comments
